article:
In 1939 two brothers, Mac and Dick McDonald, started a drive-in restaurant in San Bernadino, California. They carefully chose a busy corner for their   _  . They had  _  their own businesses for
years, first a theatre, then a barbecue restaurant, then another drive-in. But
in their new operation, they  _  a new, shortened
menu: French fries, hamburgers, and sodas. To this basic selection they  _  one new concept: quick service, no waiters or waitresses, and no  _  . Their hamburgers sold for fifteen cents. Cheese was  _  four cents. Their French fries and hamburgers had a remarkable
uniformity (,), for the brothers had   _  a strict routine for the preparation of their food, and they  insisted on  their cook's sticking to their routine. Their new drive-in became
unbelievably popular, particularly for  _  . People drove up
by the hundreds during the busy noontime. The self-service restaurant was so  _  that the brothers had allowed ten copies of their restaurant to be  _  . They were content with this modest  _  until
they met Ray Kroc.
Kroc was a (an)   _  . He met the McDonald brothers in 1954,  _  he
was selling milk shake-mixing machines. He quickly saw the unusual  _  of the brothers' fast food restaurants and bought the right to open
other  _  of their restaurants. The  _  included the right to copy the menu, the equipment, even their red
and white buildings with the golden arches.
Today McDonald's is undoubtedly a household name. Its names for its sandwiches have come to   _  hamburger in the decades since the day Ray Kroc watched people  _  up to order fifteen-cent hamburgers. In 1976, McDonald's had over $1
billion in total  _  . Its first twenty-two years is
one of the most unbelievable success stories in modern American business
history.
